Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. BALLROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Bartlet is speaking at a dinner. He stands behind the podium while important people in fancy clothes listen to him. Hanging behind him is a banner that says 'Practical Idealism'.

One night he went in and set the briefcase down and said, 'Bess, why do you suppose it is that only sons-of-bitches know how to lick a stamp?' [laughter and applause] The point is, friends, you've got to write the letter, you've got to send a fax, you've got to pick up the phone and call Western Union. You've got to contact your Congressional representative... Backstage, Leo is watching the speech as his phone rings. He answers it, while Bartlet continues in the background.
You've got to say 'Mister, I've got a friend who's neighbor is dead...
McGarry here.
'...Madam, I've got a neighbor whose friend is dead, whose husband is dead, whose mother is dead, kids are dead! Kids are dead!
What are you talking about?
'...and I wanna know, mister. I wanna know, madam...
How did it happen?
...how you intend to vote on Wednesday, so that I'll know how to vote next election...'
Well how did the wheels come off this thing?
You gotta ask 'em. You gotta ask 'em! [Applause. Josh joins Leo backstage.]
We lost five votes.
What?
We lost five votes.
Give me names.
I don't got them yet. Get on the phone.
[groans]Oh, man! JOSH gets on the phone. Somewhere backstage, Toby is watching the Bartlet on a T.V. screen.
You know, I had a civil procedure professor who said once...
Take a beat. [pause] There you go.

He said, 'When the law is on your side, argue the law; and when the facts are on your side, argue the facts... Leo and Josh are both talking on their phones, with Bartlet on T.V. screens in the background.
But it's not in cement.

...When you don't have the law on your side, when you don't have the facts on your side, bang your fist on the defense table as loud as you can.' Well, we've got the law on our side now, and we've got the facts on our side now...
Yeah, this is Josh Lyman. Please call me. I need to know what happened.

...bang our fist on the defense table, but we're not listening any more. We're not having that any more. We're gonna win on Wednesday. We're gonna win on Wednesday! Thank you all. [The crowd stands up and applauds.] God bless you, and God bless America! Bartlet works his way out of the room while 'Happy Days Are Here Again' plays. The staff follows as they all walk through the back hallways. Sam shakes Bartlet's hand.
Fantastic.
Thank you. Bartlet continues down the hall with his Secret Service AGENTS. Sam joins Toby as they continue to follow the President.
Good job.
[unenthusiastic] Yeah.
You didn't like it.
I thought it was fine.
I thought it was a hell of a lot better than fine.
[still unenthusiastic] It was good.
It was outstanding!
He blew the D section.
Toby, they're still on their feet cheering.
Yeah, I said it was fine.
[walks up] Sam, nice going.
Thank you. Tell him. [indicates Toby]
Why?
Well-
Because Sam wrote two and a half paragraphs and I wrote thirty-seven pages.
Still...
He blew the D section.
I thought it was inspired.
Why do you keep saying stuff like that to me?
[laughing] Just to watch your face turn that color. [They all go down the stairs.]
[from behind] C.J.!
[drops back] Hey, your little fan club was out in full force tonight.
Well, they like me in my tux.
Do you think I have an unusually large neck?
What the hell?
I'm just asking, 'cause one of the...
Stop talking.
What's up?
I want you to look calm while I'm telling you this.
Telling me what?
We lost five.
What do you mean?
802. Five votes jumped the fence.
[going buggy eyed] Are you kidding me?
Nice job looking calm.
Are you kidding me?
Leo just got off the phone with the whip. Last nose count, we're five votes down.
What the hell happened?
We don't know.
Give me names.
We're finding out.
[from behind] Josh.
Yeah?
[walks ahead to Mandy] Hi there.
Hi.
'Happy Days Are Here Again'?
He likes it.
Who?
The President.
We try and avoid having the President make aesthetic decisions.
I made the decision.
Right. And I don't mean to step on your toes, but you might want to rethink marrying the lines 'Kids are dead. Kids are dead!' and 'Happy Days Are Here Again.'
It's optimistic.
I'll say. Bartlet is shaking hands with someone, and then joins the group. They go down the stairs again.
Thank you. Good night. [to Toby, in front of him] Toby!
Sir.
What'd you think?
I thought my work was outstanding, Mr. President.
I thought you would.
Thanks for asking. [pause] Couldn't help but notice you got a little extemporaneous there in the D section.
Oh, you noticed that, did you?
Yes sir, I did.
Yes. I did a little polish right up there on my feet.
Yes indeed.
Right in front of everybody. I looked to the side at one point, you know. I half expected to see you coming at me with a salad fork.
Well, but for the secret service agents restraining me, sir.
Yup. Thank God for the secret service.
Bless their hearts...
[sees a couple getting friendly in the hall] Hey there, fella. She deserves a nice room and some supper.
You like doing that, don't you sir?
[smiles] Yeah. [Toby laughs.] Hey, Charlie!
[comes forward] Yes, sir?
What'd you think of the speech?
Me?
Yes, you.
Uh, I thought it was-
He means the text of the speech, Charlie, discounting the little improv in the D section.
I mean the entire speech, Charlie, and in particular the delivery.
I thought it was excellent. BARTLET and TOBY See! Toby laughs again.
See, I think what Charlie's trying to say is that in this case the singer outdistanced the song.
Really. Well, what I heard Charlie say was that the text was user-proof, although you did your level best to disprove that in the D section.
You know what, Toby?
Sir.
You're what my mother calls a pain in the ass.
Well, that's what my mother calls it too, sir.
Oh, Mr. President.
Yes, Charlie. By the way, did the First Lady call?
The First Lady called at eight forty, sir. She wished you luck and told me to tell you to take your back medicine.
My back is fine.
I have it here, sir.
Those damn things make me goofy.
Mrs. Bartlet seemed quite adamant. I'd describe her tone as being...

You don't have to describe her tone to me, Charlie. I've been married to it for 32 years. The whole group comes out of building where a crowd is waiting for them. They head for their cars. Secret Service Agents are everywhere.
Sir, I don't want to get in trouble with the First Lady...
Give me the medicine, Charlie. [takes the medicine and sticks it in his pocket] Thank you. Have a good night. I'll see you in the morning.
Yes sir.
[to the crowd] Thank you all. Bartlet waves to the crowd and gets into his limousine, as Josh and C.J. walk by towards another car.
We love you, Josh!
Thanks!
[to girls] It helps not to know him!
[into radio while tapping the car] Here we go. Move it out. The car engines start.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Sam, Toby, Mandy, and C.J. are sitting around a table, still in their fancy clothes, eating Chinese food. Leo and Josh are both on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: Leo, your food's getting cold. Want me to bring it over? Leo shakes his head and continues talking on the phone.
Seriously, I have never had dumplings quite this good.
[plaintively] Isn't my food getting cold too?
We ate your food.
C.J., you have got to try this.
Oh thanks. Try some of this.
[under his breath] Here it comes.
Yum! Oh, Sam, you gotta try the General Chow's chicken.
And the Kung Pow chicken.
With the sauce. [offers the food. Sam takes a taste.]
Oh, you gotta have it with the sauce.
[with mouth full] That's delicious!
You didn't try it with the sauce.
Will the two of you... shut up?
[to Toby] Wanna try the spicy crispy beef?
I'm really very happy with the food that I've got. Leo gets off the phone and walks over to the table. He starts dishing up.
Botrell?
It's not Botrell. I've only got two, but Botrell isn't one of them. Katzenmoyer and Wick.
I could've called that.
Sam, slide me a soda please. Sam slides a soda to Leo. Josh hangs up his phone and walks over to the table. He has ditched his jacket and untied his bow tie.
Everyone's someplace else. All I got was O'Bannon.
I didn't get O'Bannon. That's three.
Who'd you get?
Katzenmoyer and Christopher Wick.
Chris Wick?
Yeah.
It's got to be a mistake. Who told you that?
Lee Tamaki and the minority whip.
They've got bad information. There is no way Chris Wick jumped the fence.
The President just told a ballroom full of people and anyone who reads a newspaper that we're gonna pass 802 on Wednesday. We've got a 72 hour fight.
How do we do that without making noise?
What do we care about noise?
There's two things in the world you never want to let people see how you make 'em: laws and sausages.
Got it. First of all, obviously don't involve the President.
Absolutely. This is us. [pause] C.J., what's the press room going to be talking about in the next few days?
Financial disclosures.
That time again?
It's that time again.
What are you worth there, Toby?
[dryly] Well, I own this tuxedo, and I've got twenty-three bucks in my pocket.
[giggles] That's good.
Financial disclosure it is.
No, I mean, that's good.
She's right.

C.J. feed them human interest, not just, 'Look, we're disclosing assets.' People will really get a kick out of reading about how much money you guys have, especially when they find out you don't have any.
It's a pretty humiliating way of taking one for the team, isn't it?
They're going to love you for being broke, Toby.
I found that. I found that women especially can't get enough of my 1993 Dodge Dart.
How do we get the votes?

Well, setting aside Christopher Wick, and I agree with Josh. Someone's getting that wrong. Katzenmoyer and O'Bannon I buy. I'm going to guess the other two are Tillinghouse and LeBrandt. That's what we're going to hear tomorrow. Now the two of them are going to vote together on this, so we're really only going to need to get to one, and whether it's Tillinghouse or LeBrandt, and it should be Tillinghouse, we're gonna need help.
Yeah.
Who?
You're not going to like it.
Who?
The Vice President.
No way.
Leo...
No way.
Tillinghouse and the Vice...
I'm not using Hoynes.
Actually, Leo, I have to agree...
[looks at his watch] What time do you have? My watch says two o'clock?
[looks at his watch] It's two o'clock.
Did someone pay for this?
I got it.
Make sure you turn in a receipt. I gotta go home. [as he leaves] Toby, Sam, beautiful work.
Thank you.
[points at Sam with chopsticks] Two and a half paragraphs. [points at himself] Thirty-seven pages.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. LEO'S HOUSE - LATE NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo's car pulls up to his house.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Leo walks in and puts down a paper on a table. His wife, JENNY walks halfway down the stairs in her nightgown.

Dialogues.Line: Where've you been?
What do you mean?
The event was over at 10:30. I thought you were gonna come straight home.
I'm really sorry, Jenny.
What happened?
We're five votes short on 802.
[exasperated] And what could you possibly do about that at two o'clock in the morning that you can't do during normal business hours?
I can do things, Jenny. I wake people up. I meet with key staff. It's a long...
Leo... [pause] Come to bed.
Yeah, I'll be right up. [sees a box on the table, picks it up and looks at it] What's this?
It's a wristwatch.
For me?
Yes.
From you?
Yeah.
For what?
[sighs] Our anniversary. LEO looks terrible.
Come to bed.
INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Toby is sitting in his office talking with a woman named LEELA from the White House Counsel's office.
Unusual, don't you think?
I honestly couldn't say.
I'm saying, only owning one stock issue.
Yes.
It's pretty unusual.
And I'm saying I really couldn't say. I have no background or education in the stock market. I'm a speechwriter.
You're the communications director, Toby. You can't tell me you have no...
I can tell you, Leela. Ask the Treasury Secretary. Ask the Chairman of the Federal Reserve. I'm a total novice at this.
Toby...
I have never owned a share of stock until last year.
What made you buy the stock?
I use the website. I like the company.
Five thousand dollars worth?
That's right.
And now the stock is worth one hundred and twenty-five thousand?
Leela, I'm as surprised as anybody. I didn't know until the accountant called your office.
Did you know that seventy-one percent of the increase happened the day after Cal Poly professor Theodore McGregor testified to the Commerce Committee on the future of Internet stocks?
Of course I didn't. I'm telling you that I've never paid any attention... Someone knocks at the door.
Yes? Carol, pokes her head in Toby's door.
Excuse me, Toby.
Yeah.
Sam says they've got all five.
Tillinghouse?
Yeah
Thank you. Carol leaves while Toby writes something on a pad.
White House Counsel's office is going to want to investigate.
Leela, I've got forty-eight hours to a crucial floor vote. Is there any way that...?
Toby, you're the one who arranged for McGregor to testify in front of Commerce in the first place.
I grew up on the same block as Ted McGregor. He's very well respected-

No, I understand. But market analysts widely attribute the jump in technology stocks to the testimonies of, among others, your boyhood friend. [incredulously] Are you telling me you didn't know what he was going to say to the committee?

I'm telling you that not only didn't I know what he was going to say to the committee, not only didn't I care what he was going to say to the committee, but if he had sat in my office while I typed up his testimony for him. [yells] I wouldn't have understood what he was going to say to the committee!
Toby.
What!
Friend to friend.
[calms down] Yeah.
You know that manipulating the stock market, or trying to or conspiring to manipulate the market in any way...is a federal crime, right?
Are you saying I should be talking to a lawyer?
Toby, I'm saying you're talking to one right now. TOBY looks worried.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh and Sam are leaving the Oval Office. They pass Mrs. Landingham.

Dialogues.Line: So what's the range of what we're talking about?
Congratulations, Josh.
Thanks, Mrs. Landingham.
What's she congratulating you on?
I don't know. They walk out to the HALLWAY.
What's the range?
Yes.

Votes are expensive. O'Bannon's going to want the farm subsidies revisited, Katzenmoyer's gonna go back to the federal tax exempt metro link. We're talking about unions, defense contracts, possibly agency appointments and my point is that the clock's running, and we're no closer to answering the question.
Which question?
How we get five votes without giving away everything in the store. A woman passes by.
Congratulations, Josh.
Thanks.
What the hell's going on...?
We do it by giving away nothing in the store.
We can't...
I say nothing.
What're you saying?

L.B.J. never would've taken this kind of crap from Democrats in Congress. He'd have said, 'You're voting my way, in exchange for which, it is possible that I might remember your name.' [stops walking] Pal, we need to win. And I mean win. We need to take a curtain call and a victory lap. And that's how we get momentum. We get it by being tough. We give away nothing. That's what I'm taking to Leo.
And Chris Wick?
Chris Wick, I own his ass. They walk into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA to cheering and shouts of 'Congratulations'. Donna walks up.
I sense I'm being mocked.
Congratulations, Josh.
What did I do?
You won our award for best gift valued over twenty-five dollars on the financial disclosure report.
Really?
Yeah.
What won it for me?
The 1189 dollar Viennatelli silk smoking jacket from Miss Sarah Wissinger.
Ah, yes.
You're also the runner up, by the way, with the 345 dollar antique scrimshaw cigarette holder, also from Miss Sarah Wissinger.
Well, Sarah was very fond of me.
I'd imagine with that smoking jacket and the cigarette holder, you were quite the dandy.
All right, this was fun, but Sam and I are busy making critical decisions, and I'm sure you have a lot of typing to do. So I'll talk to you later.
Bye. [walks off] Sam and Josh keep going, right past Josh's office.
I'll take care of Chris Wick.
Where are you going?
[stops and looks at Sam] Where are you going?
I was following you.
I was following you. [pause] All right, don't tell anyone this happened, okay? Josh heads back towards his office as Toby comes around the corner.
Sam! I've got a problem. I need to talk to you for a few minutes.
Sure. [heads off with Toby] Leo and Margaret, come in from the entrance.
It can be Dom. It can be Kristal. She likes them both.
Which do you like?
I don't drink champagne. The important thing is that it be in a high hat.
What's that?
It's the silver bucket that rests on a tripod. In fact, the whole meal should be under sterling silver.
They'll know what that means?
Yeah.
How about music?
I'll put on a record.
You don't want a violinist?
To play the violin?
Yeah.
Is that what people get now?
I know it's available. LEO'S OFFICE. Margaret follows Leo inside.
No. 'Cause after the initial thing wears off there's just a guy with a violin in my house.
Right.
Harry Winston's sending down the choker.
It'll be here this afternoon.
It's the right size.
We can only hope.
My wife's got a great neck.
This will certainly call attention to it.
Would you stop?
You spend too much money.
And you can squeeze the life out of a nickel better than any ten people I know.
Well, excuse me for not having made forty thousand a pop on the lecture circuit.
Stop reading the disclosure reports! They're none of your business.
They're going to be printed in the newspapers in two days.
[knocks and comes in] Leo?
Josh, do women like violinists?
You thinking about taking lessons?
No, I mean to listen to next to the table.
Gets a little weird after a minute, doesn't it?
That's what I thought.
Is it Jenny's birthday?
[quietly] I forgot our anniversary.
In that case I'd shift into gear and bring on the Julliard String Quartet.
[to Margaret] Call the guy.
Perhaps Mrs. McGarry would enjoy you in a nice smoking jacket. [looks pointedly at Josh]
Leave.
Call the guy. Margaret leaves.
I'm going to see Katzenmoyer.
When?
Right now.
What're you gonna give him?
Nothing more than a wake up call. I want your permission to kick his ass.
You want to dangle his job in front of him?
Yeah.
No.
I wanna let him hear the branch creak.
We do that. It doesn't work. We can't do it again.

If it doesn't work, I back off. If it doesn't work, we give Katzenmoyer a metro link and we let O'Bannon order off the menu. If it does work, I think we get the other four votes no problem when word gets out we're not screwing around.
[gives in] I should sell tickets to this meeting.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. CAPITOL BUILDING - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh and CONGRESSMAN KATZENMOYER are strolling along in front of the Capitol Building.

Dialogues.Line: You gotta understand the people in my district, Josh.
Your constituents like the Tech 9 and the Rutger Mini 14, do they? They go quail hunting with an Uzi?
I won with fifty-two percent of the vote. From the moment I'm sworn in I need to raise ten thousand dollars a week just to run a reelection campaign.
And you're not doing so well.
Averaging sixty-five hundred. That's money I can just squeak by with. The NRA makes me a target in the next election. I lose, plain and simple. Ask me two years from now. I'll be there for you.
Fifty-five thousand more people will be shot and killed with guns two years from now, but that's very much beside the point.
What is your point?
Forgive my bluntness, and I say this with all due respect, Congressman, but vote yes, or you're not even going to be on the ballot two years from now.
How do you figure?
You're going to lose in the primary.
There's no Democrat running against me.
Sure there is.
Who?
Whomever we pick.
You're bluffing.
[shrugs] Okay. [starts to walk away. Katzenmoyer looks worried.]
I'm in your own party!
Doesn't seem to be doing us much good now, does it?
It's an incumbent Democrat. You'll go to the press and endorse a challenger?

No sir. We're going to do it in person. See, you won with fifty-two percent, but the President took your district with fifty-nine. And I think it's high time we come back and say thanks. Do you have any idea how much noise Air Force One makes when it lands in Eau Claire, Wisconsin? We're going to have a party, Congressman. You should come, it's gonna be great. And when the watermelon's done, right in town square, right in the band gazebo... You guys got a band gazebo?
Josh...

Doesn't matter, we'll build one. Right in the band gazebo, that's where the President is going to drape his arm around the shoulder of some assistant DA we like. And you should have your camera with you. You should get a picture of that. 'Cause that's gonna be the moment you're finished in Democratic politics. President Bartlet's a good man. He's got a good heart. He doesn't hold a grudge. [puts on sunglasses] That's what he pays me for. [walks away]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam and Toby are in the office talking. Toby is sitting on the couch. Sam is standing in front of him.

Dialogues.Line: 125,000 dollars?
Could you stop saying that!?
Sure.
How much trouble am I in?
Well, there's two kinds of trouble here: actual trouble and PR trouble.
Talk about actual trouble.
You're in no actual trouble.
Really?
Absolutely not.
Good.
But I'd hire a lawyer anyway.
Why?
Because technically you've committed a felony punishable by imprisonment and fines reaching into the millions.
[gets up to pace] All right, let's move away from actual trouble for a second and let's talk about...
Perception.
Yes.
We've done nothing wrong, yet the perception of those who would choose to glance only at a snapshot would be embarrassing.
Say nothing of damaging to the President.
[brightly] Indeed.
Why are you talking like this?
Because I can't help but be reminded of a bright and energetic young White House deputy who took no end of admonition and grief because of a woman he was friends with.
I totally backed you up on that!
Which is why I couldn't be happier to help you. It's like being able to do something for my older brother. I'm your guy on this. What's your level of confidence?
[glumly] Absolutely none.
Who else knows about this?
Anyone who saw the report.
Everybody has the report, but you really have to study it to have...

[comes to the open door] Excuse me, Toby. I was heading out for lunch and I'm a little short. You wouldn't happen to have 125,000 dollars I could borrow, would you? [dissolves into laughter as she walks away]
I got your back on this, buddy.
I am so... completely screwed.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - MORNING
Scenes.Description: C.J. is standing at the podium addressing a small number of reporters.

Dialogues.Line: 145 dollar Armani cravat, which I'm pretty sure is a necktie. It was a gift from his brother-in-law. He gave it away to the Salvation Army. Information I'm sure the President would prefer his brother-in-law did not have. Laughter.
C.J., I'm curious about the President's farm in Manchester. The property value increased seven hundred and fifty thousand dollars. What's that due to?
Secret Service improvements.
Can you do into detail please?
The property now includes a helipad and the ability to run a global war from the sun porch. Laughter. Josh comes in and stands to the side, waiting for C.J. to finish.
That's all for now, folks. Later this afternoon we'll do Deputy Chief of Staff Joshua Lyman. [joins Josh and head out]
Thanks for the promo.
They really can't get enough of you. HALLWAY. They walk out.
I got Katzenmoyer.
He's back?
Along with O'Bannon and LeBrandt.
You got three!
Chris Wick's waiting for me right now. I don't know what his story is, but I'm not that worried.
You worried about Tillinghouse?
I can't get him without the Vice President. Leo's got to lighten up on that. C.J. and JOSH walk inside the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE where Donna finds Josh.
Get Wick first. And then we'll deal with it. [walks off]
Josh.
Yeah.
Congressman Wick is waiting in the Mural Room.
I know.
He's been waiting twenty minutes.
I know.
You have a legislative liaison meeting in fifteen minutes.
I know.
And then the East Asia briefing.
I know.
All right. Well, then this entire conversation served only as a reminder.
Actually, it only served as a colossal waste of time and energy. Keep up the good work. Josh goes inside THE MURAL ROOM. CONGRESSMAN CHRIS WICK, a very young looking man, and his staff are waiting.
Congressman.
Dude! The young Congressman shakes Josh's hand, and then starts to introduce him to staff.
Uh, John...
Right. [to staff] Guys, could you wait outside for a minute, please. The Congressman and I want to talk about old times.
Go ahead.
[watches as the staff leaves] Thanks. Thanks a lot. Could you close the door please? [to Wick] Is that supposed to impress me, you have a staff?
Josh...
I told the House minority whip he was crazy. No way is Chris Wick jumping the fence. Do you have any idea how stupid this makes me look?
Uh, look. About that, dude.
Shove it, dude. We're not in a frat house anymore.
What the hell, man?
Name for me please the weapons banned in this bill and why you feel they should be legal.
Look, I realize I should have called...
Let's start here. Name for me please the weapons banned in this bill.
If you'd let me explain...
You don't have a clue.
No. That's not true.
Mac 90.
Listen...
The PCR. NFR. Anything ring a bell?
My aides were supposed to...
They're both copycats of the AR 15 assault rifle that was banned two years ago. It's the exact same gun.
Calm down...
It's back. They just changed the grip. How 'bout the Pat Maxi?
Semi-automatic, muzzle barrel...
[yells] It's a grenade launcher!
Yes, I'm trying to...

You know, I realize as an adult not everyone shares my view of the world. And with an issue as hot as gun control I'm prepared to accept a lot of different points of view as being perfectly valid. But we can all get together on the grenade launcher, right?
Josh...
I put you in your seat. I got you elected to the House of Representatives.
Yeah, and now you guys think I'm on the leash. Look, I get taken for granted, Josh. I've one photo op with the President. One. Me and sixteen other freshmen. That makes me weak.
You're not serious.
I've been here over a year. Huh. Where's the courtship? This isn't ego. A relationship with the White House is currency around here and I need some.
You're voting down a measure that would restrict the sale of deadly weapons because nobody invited you to the cool kid's table?
Got your attention.
You know, I'm so sick of Congress I could vomit. [starts to leave but turns back] What do you want?
A round of golf.
President doesn't play golf.
What does he play?
Chess.
Over brandy. With the White House photographers and we're fine.
He's going to kick your ass, you know.
Whatever. You know, I really don't appreciate you calling...

Chris, you're a Congressman. You've gotta make that real. This time it was me in the Mural Room. Trust me when I tell you, you do not wanna have this conversation with the guy who works next door. [leaves and sees the staff waiting outside] You guys take care. [walks away]

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo, C.J. and Mandy are admiring the gorgeous pearl choker Leo bought for his wife. Toby is seated, and Sam walks in the door.

Dialogues.Line: Wow!
Wow is right.
It is so beautiful.
Excellent choice, my friend.
Stop looking at me like that. You're talking about Jenny.
[backpedaling] My point being only that it should flatter her neck in ways that should please you.
Can I try it on?
No.
Can I rub it against my teeth?
No.
Could we possibly talk about me?
Are you saying I'm going to stretch it?
[comes in] Leo, I got four out of five. I'm absolutely convinced we need the Vice President to get Tillinghouse.
We're all agreed on that.
No.
This needs a Texan.
I have a different idea.
What?
I go to Richardson.
You've already been through this with Richardson.
The entire caucus. Let's not get 'em any more pissed off at us than they are already.
I'll talk to Richardson alone.
You have to do it quietly and right now.
[calls] Margaret!
Call me as soon as you've got it. [leaves]
[enters] Yes sir?
I need to see Mark Richardson out of the office. Margaret leaves.
You know, Toby. You could afford to buy one of those now if you want.
There's literally no one in the world that I don't hate right now. Everyone laughs except for Toby.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE LINCOLN MEMORIAL - DAY
Scenes.Description: CONGRESSMAN RICHARDSON, an imposing African American, is walking with Leo near the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

Dialogues.Line: Let me guess. Josh got Katzenmoyer and the rest of them back in the boat. You came to me instead of Tillinghouse because you don't wanna use Hoynes.
We need this one, Mark.
I'm voting no, Leo.
Mark, it's all we could get right now and you know it.
You didn't work hard enough.
We did.
What happened to the Tech DC 9 and the Tech 22? What happened to the Striker 12 and the Street Sweeper?
We had to lose 'em.
You never fought for 'em.
We have to do this inch by inch. You know how this works.
No, I know how you guys work.
That is out of line, Congressman. Guns are number one on my list of priorities and I've never moved the President off of that.
Keeping the White House strong is number one on your list of priorities.

If the White House isn't strong, it doesn't really matter what number two on my list is. God, Mark. The bodies being wheeled into the emergency room are black. These guns aren't going to Scottsdale, Mark, they're going to Detroit, they're going to Philadelphia. An entire generation of African American men are being eaten alive by drugs and poverty.

Well, I'm encouraged to hear the White House has discovered there's a drug problem in this country. I mean your penetrating insight is matched only by the courage displayed in the authorship of this bill.
Mark, for God sake...

Not the three-inch grip, but the two-inch grip. With the forty-gauge barrel and the thirty round clip, not the twenty round clip. With a three-day wait to run a check to see if you're crazy. As if wanting the gun wasn't a pretty good heads up in the first place. No, this is for show. And I think it's an unconscionable waste of the taxpayer's money to have it printed, signed and photocopied, to say nothing of enforced. No, I want the guns, Leo. You write a law that can save some lives. I'll sign it. In the mean time, please don't tell me how to be a leader of black men. You look like an idiot. [walks away leaving Leo looking stunned]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Mandy is reading the financial disclosures. Josh is standing behind his desk.

Dialogues.Line: Someone gave you a year's supply of fruit?
Yes.
Why?
There are people who like me.
Why?
[pokes her head in] It's Leo.
[picks up the phone] What happened? [listens, then groans]
That's it. He needs to talk to Hoynes. We'll set up a meeting.
Yeah Leo. We're going to set up a meeting for you with the Vice President. [listens] Good.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. LEO'S HOUSE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Leo's car pulls up to his house to find a taxi waiting.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Leo comes in and finds Jenny's bags sitting by the door. He walks over to the dining room and sees the dinner he ordered untouched on the table.

Dialogues.Line: Jenny?
[walks into the room wearing the choker] I'm still here.
What's going on?
Leo...
What's going on?
Honey, I'm so sorry you went to all this trouble.
It wasn't any trouble.
[sighs] I can't do this anymore. This is crazy. I don't want to live like this. I just can't.
I'm sorry about the anniversary. I just...
It's not the anniversary. It's everything. It's the whole thing.
This is the most important thing I'll ever do, Jenny. I have to do it well.
It's not more important than your marriage.

[emphatically] It is more important than my marriage right now. These few years, while I'm doing this, yes, it's more important than my marriage. I... I didn't decide to do this myself, Jenny. There were many discussions...
I think if you can find the time to...
I'm five votes down, Jenny! And I need to win. I met with the staff...
You made the time.
I made the time tonight.
You didn't make the time tonight.
I hired a whole...
Margaret phoned to confirm your nine o'clock meeting with the Vice President.
[beat] I was going to slip out for 45 minutes...
Leo...
I was going to be right back.
I can't. Really.
I don't suppose we could postpone this discussion until... It's just the past couple of days...
I have to go now.
Okay.
[puts on jacket] I'll be at the Watergate.
Okay.
And I'll talk to you later.
[with a catch in his throat] You'll call me?
Yeah. [starts to pick up bags]
You... you want me to carry that to the cab?
It's okay. [opens door]
[almost in tears] Call me before you go to sleep.
Okay. Jenny shuts the door behind her, leaving Leo looking devastated.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE VICE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Hoynes is sitting in his office reading a newspaper. His secretary, JANEANE comes to the door.

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me sir, Leo McGarry's here.
Send him in. [gets up and greets Leo as he walks in]
Good evening, Mr. Vice President.
Come on in. Thanks, Janeane.
Thanks. Janeane leaves.
What did you need to see me about?
Um... I came in to talk to you about 802. We lost five votes.
I know.
We got four of them back, but I was stupid with Richardson. And now it's Tillinghouse, so I wanted to talk to you about that and...
Leo, are you feeling okay? Sit down. Go on. Sit down. [They both sit.]
Jenny and I are splitting up and it just happened and I'm feeling a little, um...
[calls] Janeane! Janeane appears at the door, waiting for instructions.
If I could just have a glass of water.
Janeane, could you get me a glass of ice water please. [to Leo] Leo, it's going to be fine. These things happen.
Yeah.
I mean, do you... you wanna talk about it at all? Leo shakes his head in answer as Janeane returns with the water.
Thank you. [takes a large drink] Anyway...
I'll see Tillinghouse.
[surprised] Yeah?
I'll see him tomorrow morning.
You'll deliver him?
It's a done deal.
I don't need to tell you we need this win.
I think we're home.
Thanks, John. I want you to know the President and I appreciate it. [starts to leave]
Leo. Do you mind if I ask you a question?
What?
When was the last time you went to a meeting?
A.A.? What meeting could I possibly go to?
Mine.
John, tell me you are not showing your face-

Leo, I have got my own meeting. Every week. The downstairs office here at the O.E.O.B. at 11 p.m. There are nine of us three senators, two cabinet secretaries, one federal judge and two agency directors. There's an agent outside, the whole thing looks like a card game.
Do I have enemies in that room?
All our people.
I had no idea.
Neither will anyone else. You should think about it. Leo nods and gets up to leave.
Now, are you driving?
Uh. No, I've got my guy.
Good. Good evening. I'm sorry about Jenny.
Call me after Tillinghouse.
It's in the bag.
Good night John.
Good night Leo.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Josh leaves his office, where Mandy is waiting in ambush. They head for the Oval Office.
Hi there.
How you doing?
Sarah Wissinger?
Yes. A smoking jacket and a cigarette holder. Both declared items. I am clean as a whistle.
You received these gifts on July 3rd.
I'm sensing trouble, but I can't quite...
You and I didn't break up until July 9th.
Ah, there it was, right in front of my face.
She was giving you presents on July 3rd?
You knew I knew Sarah.
I didn't know she was giving you presents.
They weren't by way of saying 'Thanks for sleeping with me' if that's what you mean.
[walks ahead of him into Oval Office] Don't talk to me. Mandy and Josh enter THE OVAL OFFICE, where Toby, Sam, and C.J. are waiting.
Hey.
What's going on?
Hoynes is having breakfast with Tillinghouse.
Sarah Wissin-slut gave him the jacket on July 3rd.
I really thought a nice by-product of not going out with you anymore would be that you wouldn't yell at me anymore.
That was a bit unrealistic, wasn't it?
Where's the President?
Haven't seen him. Leo comes in from his office. Everyone turns to look at him.
Leo, how'd it go?
What do you mean?
Last night.
[realizes what they're talking about and puts on a good face] Oh. Oh, great.
She liked the choker?
Yeah.
And the violinist?
Uh. You-You're right. After a couple of minutes it's strange having him there. But, uh, you know um... [faking smile] She ate it up, so... They all congratulate him. Then a pause.
Where's the President?

His back is pretty bad today. He canceled the morning. He'll stay in bed and make some calls. We should move this to my... Leo stops as Bartlet enters from outside. He's wearing jeans and a Notre Dame sweatshirt and is looking slightly drugged.
Hey!
Mr. President. I thought you were staying in bed.
Oh, I feel fine.
Uh... Maybe you should get back to the residence.
Hmm?
I said, maybe you should get back to the residence. Maybe you should lie down.
Absolutely no need. I'm fine. What's going on here?
Nothing you need to concern yourself with, Mr. President. Merely a perception issue regarding Toby and the financial disclosure.
I like to... [mimes rolling sleeves] Roll up my sleeves and you know... [pause] ...get involved.
Mr. President. Did you by any chance take your back pills?
I don't mind telling you C.J. I was in a little pain there.
Which did you take, sir, the Vicadin or the Percocet?
I wasn't supposed to take 'em both?
Okay. Mr. President, we're going to have someone take you back to bed.
No no no. Sit sit sit. All sit down. Bartlet sits between Toby and Sam.

One of you's got a problem and I'm here to help. You guys are like family. You've always been there for me, always been loyal. Honest, hard working, good people, and I love you all very much. I don't say that often enough. So tell me what the problem is, Toby. [puts his hand on Sam's knee]
[surprised] I'm Sam, sir.
Sam, of course you are. He puts his arm around Sam as they all watch incredulously.

Sir. Sir... The situation basically is this. I arranged for a friend to testify to Commerce on Internet stocks while simultaneously, but unrelated to that, bought a technology issue which, partly due to my friend's testimony, shot through the roof.
Toby. [pause] Toby. Toby. Toby. [pause] Toby's a nice name, don't you think?
[to Leo] Could we possibly do this meeting at another time? Leo starts to get up.

No, no, no, no. Please, Leo. I know my body. I mean, you know, my muscles are not, you know, but my mind is sharp. I can focus. I'm focused. You all know that about me. Here's what I think we ought to do... [long pause] Was I just saying something?
[stands and calls] Mrs. Landingham!
Look, I think we need to run through some options.
[comes in] Yes, sir?
Get Charlie.
Let's start at the bottom.
What do you mean?
There's always resignation.
Hot damn! Now you're talking.
I think she meant me, Mr. President.
Ah.
Well of course Toby's not going to resign. I think we're making more of this than we...
I got it!
I've got a lawyer from the White House Counsel's office-
I got it!
What?
Counsel's office releases a statement through C.J. Using the strongest possible language we make it very clear that there's been no wrongdoing of any kind.
Yes.

But to avoid even the appearance of impropriety, Toby has agreed to reduce his salary for one year to one dollar, and immediately cash out his stock issue thereby relieving the taxpayer of the burden. Toby looks shocked.
Done.
Wait.
Good, Sam.
Thank you.
No, no, it's not good. Actually, it stinks.
Toby, you're a great writer, do you know that?
Well, thank you very much sir.
Here, give me a hug.
[looks pained] Leo!
Come on. Give us a hug. [hugs Toby] There you go.
[walks in] Excuse me, Mr. President.
Charlie!
Mr. President, I left you alone for two minutes.
Charlie's a great name.
Thank you. Sir, you have to go back to bed.
I'm going. I'm going. [gets up] Before I go, please let me just say this. [sighs] I'm seriously thinking about getting a dog.
Well, feel better Mr. President. Charlie leads Bartlet out as everyone grins after them.
Maybe an Irish setter, Charlie. What do you think?
I think that's great sir.
[to Toby] So, how do you feet there, big guy?
[dryly] Like I just got screwed with my pants on.
Excellent.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE VICE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Hoynes is having breakfast with CONGRESSMAN TILLINGHOUSE, a Texan with a very nasal accent.

Dialogues.Line: Honest to goodness, John, this isn't a political maneuver.
I know.
I'm voting my conscience.
I know.
You can't put the toothpaste back in the tube. Two hundred and forty million guns out there. How're you gonna get them back?
You can't.
Of course not. And as long as they've got a gun, I want my wife to have a gun, I want my daughter to have a gun, and damn it, I want one too.
Makes perfect sense.
You might wanna mention to Josh Lyman that Congressmen don't appreciate being bullied like ill-behaved school children.
Yes.
Katzenmoyer, O'Bannon, LeBrandt, this new kid, Christopher Wick. These are grown men, with pride and dignity. They can't be manhandled.
They're pretty pissed, are they?
Behind closed doors they're screaming bloody murder, and are talking about political retribution.
I don't blame 'em.
Reality is reality.
Yes. Which is why I'd like very much for you to do the following, Cal. I want you to vote yes on the resolution.
[surprised] John?
And you might want to mention this conversation to Representatives Katzenmoyer, O'Bannon, LeBrandt, and Wick.
[smiles] Why, John, you do seize the moment, don't you?
You've got a roll call.
Tell me something. What's in it for me?
Right now?
Yeah.
Nothing.
Then why am I handing you a personal political victory?
Because I'm going to be President of the United States one day, and you're not.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WASHINGTON, D.C. - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: We see the night view of Washington, D.C., while various news reports are heard.

Dialogues.Line: The restrictions, while not considered sweeping, do include the Mini 9 and the Rutger 14. Again, White House senior aides had hoped that this would serve as a much-needed victory for the President, but it's the Vice President who seems to be receiving most of the credit from some Congressional Democrats...
...were quick to praise Vice President John Hoynes for stepping in and securing the one vote victory...

Mark Richardson, leader of the Congressional black caucus, a man, I should add, who's seldom at a loss for words, had no comment tonight. None. You have to ask yourself, is this an intentional snub to his old friend Jed Bartlet?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo, Toby, Josh, C.J., Sam, Mandy and Donna are watching the telecasts.

Dialogues.Line: Unbelievable.
I don't believe it.
You loosen the ketchup bottle and he pops the top off.
And keeps the ketchup.
Sorry, Leo. You saw this one coming through the Holland Tunnel.
We got what we deserved. It was hubris and we got what we deserved. [gets up to leave] Night everyone. Everyone says good night. Leo walks away, but turns back to Josh, who's not looking happy.
Listen. We won. [leaves]
Where's the President?
He's asleep.
Wake him up. Josh leaves.
Toby.
Wake him now.
Let's leave it till tomorrow, Toby. Let's leave it till tomorrow. C.J. fiddles with a Magic Eight Ball.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE VICE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Hoynes is sitting at his desk. Janeane comes to the door.

Dialogues.Line: Sir. Uh, Josh Lyman is here. He was wondering if he could see you a moment.
Sure.
[walks in] Evening Mr. Vice President.
Josh. Nice victory.
Are you talking about the bill or are you talking about my smoking jacket?
[laughs] I heard about that. No, I was talking about the bill.
It's a crappy law.
Nah.
No, it is. I should know. I helped write it.
You did very well.
I'd say it's roughly the equivalent of fighting the war against tobacco by banning certain color matchbook covers.
[laughs] Well, these things happen slowly.
I'd say you did well, sir. In fact, you might be the only one who did. I just came by to say congratulations.
[comes to the door] Mr. Vice President.
Right, Janeane. I'm on my way. [gets up and puts on coat] Josh.
Yes sir?
[walks to Josh and pats him on the shoulder] Welcome to the NFL. Josh watches him leave.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OLD EXECUTIVE OFFICE BUILDING  - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo walks down a flight of stairs into a basement hallway of the O.E.O.B. There is a Secret Service Agent standing by the door.

Dialogues.Line: Something I could help you with, Mr. McGarry?
[looks apprehensive] Yeah. I'm here for the card game. The agent nods and opens the door.
Thank you. Leo walks into the room, looks around nervously, and closes the door behind him.
